content.webTitle: Commonwealth Games 2014: Nicola Adams eases past Oluwatoyin Oladeji

fields.headline: Commonwealth Games 2014: Nicola Adams eases past Oluwatoyin Oladeji
fields.bodyText: A little bit of history was made in arena two here as women were allowed into the boxing ring at the Commonwealth Games for the first time, 84 years after the men. First up, in the flyweight division, was Michaela Walsh, a 21-year-old from Northern Ireland. “It was brilliant, I was just so excited, like a kid on Christmas morning.” She beat Thessa Dumas, from Mauritius, posed for a few photos with Dame Mary Peters and then started tossing a few threats in the direction of Nicola Adams. “I’d love to meet her. She may be the golden girl now but now there is a new golden girl coming.” Adams, whose gold medal at London 2012 was one of the highlights of those Games, was top of the bill and last on for the evening, well after 11pm. Plenty stayed late to see her fight Nigeria’s Oluwatoyin Oladeji. In June Adams lost for the first time since she won that gold, defeated on points by a Bulgarian boxer in the quarter-finals of the European Championships in Bucharest. She was suffering from a shoulder injury at the time, which she has since recovered from. Mindful that, as Walsh showed, “everybody will be coming for me now I’m Olympic champion”, Adams promised before the Games to “box like every fight is the final”. She did not need to go that hard against Oladeji, a decent fighter who was ranked 33 at the 2012 world championships and won a bronze in the 2014 African Championships. Instead Adams kept a lot back but did just enough to earn unanimous decisions in all four rounds and win 3-0 on points. Adams really opened up only in the final round, when she threw a few brisk combinations that left Oladeji reeling and the crowd roaring. “She was really tough, really determined,” Adams said. She did not seem too troubled. “It feels amazing being here. I’ve had a fantastic reception in Glasgow. These Games rank really highly, as high as the Olympics for me.” As for Walsh, Adams added: “I’m not worried about meeting her at all. I concentrate on my grass and I don’t worry about how green everyone else’s grass is looking.” She is enjoying being the favourite. “The fact that everybody thinks I can win, that I will win gold here, gives me the confidence to keep going on believing I can win it.” The only disappointing thing was that she had not been allowed to wear a bandana, in the green-and-blue tartan of the Adams clan, which she had been sent by a 16-year-old fan. Adams is part of a three-strong women’s team in Glasgow, along with two other fighters from the Great Britain squad at the London Olympics – Savannah Marshall at middleweight and Natasha Jonas at lightweight. She got a better reception than a couple of the other English boxers on the bill. Anthony Fowler, the cousin of the former Liverpool footballer Robbie Fowler, got a chance to play the pantomime villain in his middleweight bout against Scotland’s Kieran Smith – and he relished every minute of it. He flashed a few grins to acknowledge the jeers and held his arms aloft in celebration after each round, although he only edged them. “All those boos really fired me up,” he said. “I love performing. That was one of the best nights of my life so far.” Smith, 21, was so high on the adrenaline of the occasion that he rushed in from the first bell. “Obviously his coach has got him fired up and said ‘look, you’re at home, so let’s get stuck into him’,” said Fowler. “But that’s played into my hands.” He picked him off with strong scoring shots. Smith started to hesitate. “As soon as he was thinking twice about coming in it got a little bit easier,” Fowler said. “I said to him in the clinches, ‘That’s easy that, son.’ But really he was very impressive. He took some big shots and he gave the crowd their money’s worth.” England’s Qais Ashafq also won in the bantam category. He will now fight Scotland’s Joe Ham on Wednesday. “I have fought the English guy twice, I have beaten him and he has beaten me,” said Ham. “We know each other but he is not beating me in front of this crowd.”
